titlePart.text: GENERAL MEASURES FOR PRODUCING AND MAINTAINING EFFECTIVE FUNCTIONING OF MACHINES OR INSTALLATIONS
ROTARY BODIES OTHER THAN GEARING ELEMENTS

noteParagraph.text: The phrase "Rotary bodies other than gearing elements" in the sub-class title, and the relevant groups and , cover any element which rotates so far as its features are affected only by the fact that it rotates.

titlePart.text: Mechanical means for transmitting movement in a flexible sheathing
Means for transmitting linear movement in a flexible sheathing, e.g. "Bowden mechanisms"
Arrangements for transmitting movement to or from the flexible member
Construction of the end-piece of the flexible member
Attachment thereof to the flexible member
in which the end-piece is guided rectilinearly
in which the end portion of the flexible member is laid along a curved surface of a pivoted member
Construction of flexible members moved to and fro in the sheathing

titlePart.entryReference: features relating to lubrication , to cooling

titlePart.text: assembled of several parts, e.g. by welding
Shape of crankshafts or eccentric-shafts having regard to balancing

titlePart.entryReference: constructional features of crank-pins per se

titlePart.text: with return cranks, i.e. a second crank carried by the crank-pin
Constructions of connecting-rod heads or piston-rod connections rigid with crossheads
Connecting-rods or like links pivoted at both ends
Constructions of connecting-rods with constant length
with elastic intermediate part or fluid cushion

titlePart.entryReference: lubrication of connecting-rods in connection with crankshafts

titlePart.text: Arrangements for adjusting play in bearings, operating either automatically or not
titlePart.entryReference: bearings adjustable for play in general
fastening crank-pins to webs, crank-pins integral with cranks ,
rubber springs with stiff outer sleeve and inner sleeve or pin

titlePart.text: Other joints having more than one degree of angular freedom, i.e. universal joints
incorporating flexible connections, e.g. leaf springs
Rolls, drums, discs, or the like
titlePart.entryReference: special adaptations, see the relevant classes

titlePart.text: Bearings with only partial enclosure of the member to be borne
Bearings with local support at two or more points
Construction of rotary bodies to resist centrifugal force
with tiltably-supported segments, e.g. Michell bearings
with tiltably-supported segments, e.g. Michell bearings
for supporting the end face of a shaft or other member, e.g. footstep bearings
for both radial and axial load
characterised by features not related to the direction of the load
specially adapted for operating in water
with floating brasses or bushes, rotatable at a reduced speed
with arrangements compensating for thermal expansion
with devices affected by abnormal or undesired conditions, e.g. for preventing overheating, for safety
Systems consisting of a plurality of sliding-contact bearings
with bearing balls essentially of the same size in one or more circular rows
with a single row of balls
with two or more rows of balls
for supporting the end face of a shaft or other member, e.g. footstep bearings
for both radial and axial load
with a single row of balls
with two or more rows of balls
with loose spacing bodies, e.g. balls, between the bearing balls
with bearing rollers essentially of the same size in one or more circular rows, e.g. needle bearings
with a single row of rollers
with two or more rows of rollers
for supporting the end face of a shaft or other member, e.g. footstep bearings
for both radial and axial load
with a single row of rollers
with two or more rows of rollers
with loose spacing bodies between the rollers
with two or more rows of needles
Bearings with both balls and rollers
Other types of ball or roller bearings
with devices affected by abnormal or undesired conditions
Systems consisting of a plurality of bearings with rolling friction
with intermediate floating rings rotating at reduced speed
in which the rolling bodies of one bearing differ in diameter from those of another
Combinations of sliding-contact bearings with ball or roller bearings
Bearings adjustable for aligning or positioning
Bearings, parts of which are eccentrically adjustable with respect to each other
Bearings adjustable for wear or play
Elastic or yielding bearings or bearing supports
titlePart.entryReference: shock-damping bearings for watches or clocks

titlePart.text: Ball or roller bearings, e.g. with resilient rolling bodies
by means of parts of rubber or like materials
titlePart.entryReference: with sliding surfaces of rubber or synthetic rubber
construction of units comprising rigid inner and outer members with rubber or the like between them

titlePart.text: primarily for axial load, e.g. for vertically-arranged shafts
Bearings for parts moving only linearly
in which the rolling bodies circulate partly without carrying load
Arrangements for covering or protecting the ways

titlePart.entryReference: preventing relative movement between machine parts in general , e.g.

titlePart.text: Bearings for parts which both rotate and move linearly
in which the rolling bodies circulate partly without carrying load
using magnetic or electric supporting means
with moving member supported by a fluid cushion formed, at least to a large extent, otherwise than by movement of the shaft, e.g. hydrostatic air-cushion bearings
Special methods for making bearings or parts thereof
titlePart.entryReference: metal-working or like operations, see the relevant classes

titlePart.text: Sliding surface mainly made of metal
Attachment of brasses, bushes, or linings to the bearing housing
Use of special materials or surface treatments, e.g. for rust-proofing
titlePart.entryReference: the materials or treatments themselves, see the relevant classes, e.g.

titlePart.text: Sliding surface consisting mainly of graphite
Sliding surface consisting mainly of wood or fibrous material
Sliding surface consisting mainly of plastics
Sliding surface consisting mainly of rubber or synthetic rubber
titlePart.entryReference: of interest apart from the surface itself

titlePart.text: with different areas of the sliding surface consisting of different materials
made from a number of discs, rings, rods, or other members
with embedded reinforcements shaped as frames or meshed materials
Parts of ball or roller bearings
with bearing-surfaces other than cylindrical, e.g. tapered
with grooves in the bearing surfaces
made from wire or sheet-metal strips
for multiple rows of rollers or needles
formed of interconnected members, e.g. chains
with no part entering between, or touching, the bearing surfaces of the rollers
made from wire, strips, or sheet metal
Special parts or details in view of lubrication
with a diaphragm, disc, or ring, with or without resilient members
Arrangements for electrostatic or magnetic action against dust or other particles
in the case of sliding-contact bearings
in the case of ball or roller bearings

Fixing them onto shaft or in housing

titlePart.text: Fixing them on the shaft or housing with interposition of an element
between shaft and inner race ring
between housing and outer race ring
using pressure fluid as mounting aid

Preventing damage to bearings during storage or transport thereof or when otherwise out of use
Placing rolling bodies in cages or bearings
by deforming the cages or the races
